response.answer_text: When you said regular light bulbs I would take it as CFL lamps or fluorescent tube lights here. All Fluorescent tube lights or CFL lamps with cool-white Color temperature(visible light source Color output) is in spectrum of 6500k as per chromaticity diagram(hence Tungsten/GLS bulbs are ruled out here as they emit Warm while/yellowish light spectrum in range of 2700k-3000k). This spectrum overlaps with UV light spectrum as well, so light sources from 6000k and above(slightly bluish white) does emit some amount of UV light, which is invincible to human eye anyway. To avoid this, Color temp needs to be brought down to 5700K (keeping +_300K tolerance) by changing composition of flouroscence, which is practically difficult in Fluorescent or CFL light source due to their design technology with phosphor composition as flourescence component converting blue light in visible white light. However adjusting phosphor composition in LED is relatively flexible to change the Color temp of light. So yes, UV is present in (most of!) these two kind of light sources, but note that it is also present in LED light sources if they are designed with Color temp 6000k & above. Now talking about infrared light, IR is also invisible light spectrum to human eye, however it isn’t pertaining to Color of light source. It is more of heat quotient in light. So when you are under any artificial light source like GLS/tungsten bulb or cfl, you experience warmth in it. It also interferes with signals of electronic equipment. The reason being, these light sources emit IR in the direction of light spectrum itself. LED also emits IR, but since it is not in the same direction of light, you don’t experience warmth in it’s light. Light is emitted from front surface of LED chip and heat is emitted from the back side of it and usually driven into heat dissipation mechanism. I hope this helps!

In general the answer is no. The potential for UV emission varies with the technology. Ordinary incandescent bulbs - the kind with a glowing filament - no way. There’s little enough emission from those in the blue region of the visible spectrum, and essentially none at all at the UV wavelengths. Similarly, LED bulbs (which use “white” LEDs - these are actually blue LEDs with a yellow phosphor coating over the LED itself) don’t emit any UV to speak of. Fluorescent tubes have the potential for UV emission, but standard white fluorescents are designed to emit very little. The common fluorescent tube is actually an example of a mercury vapor gas-discharge tube, and the mercury vapor emits short wavelength UV when excited. But this UV emission is converted to visible light by the phosphor coating on the inner surface of the glass tube, and relatively little of the UV makes it through to the outside (and this can be further reduced by adding UV-opaque materials to the tube). But the “blacklight” tubes you may be familiar with are simply fluorescent tubes designed to emit certain wavelengths of UV light (for consumer “blacklights,” the much less harmful long-wavelength UV) and lack the phosphor layer that would otherwise convert the UV to visible “white” light.

No, they do not. First of all, lightbulbs are spectacularly dimmer than sunlight. You can see this by taking even a bright bulb into daylight. You can barely notice the light difference except very close to the bulb, much closer than you would normally get indoors.Incandescent bulbs mostly emit in the green, yellow and red. The amount of UV is negligible.LEDs and fluorescent bulbs use a similar method to produce white light. They actually produce blue light which is then absorbed by a phosphor and re-emitted at lower wavelengths allowing some of the blue light to pass through unaffected. I’ve looked at the spectrum of LEDs and there is no UV. Fluorescent bulbs do use mercury vapor and this has some small amount of emission in the UV but it also passes through a phosphor to produce white light. The amount of UV is also negligible.There are many more important things to worry about than UV from artificial light!

Traditional incandescent bulbs emit almost no ultra-violet, and a huge amount of infra-red. Which is why they get so hot and are so inefficient. Florescent tubes should not emit ultra-violet. They create it internally, but it is shifted to visible by the phosphor coating on the tube. However, a badly made one may leak a bit. They don’t get very hot and therefore emit little infra-red. LED light bulbs create blue light, which is then spread to other colours by phosphors. They will therefore create little UV or IR. So the only bulbs which might emit serious UV are fluorescent, and only if badly made or damaged. The only ones which emit serious IR are old fashioned incandescents.

LED light bulbs are based on semiconductor devices that emit blue or violet light and are physically incapable of emitting any UV. (UV LEDs do exist but are not used for ordinary lighting). Halogen incandescent bulbs emit a tiny amount of UV. Fluorescent tubes and CFL lights can emit somewhat greater quantities of UV. If they are enclosed in a plastic diffuser envelope (some bulb-like CFLs) or behind a plastic diffuser (many striplights), the plastic blocks the UV. All are negligible compared to sunlight. There are devices made specifically to emit UV, which are not normally referred to as “light bulbs”.

Incandescents emit a LOT of infrared (as much or more as they emit in visible light) and very little to no UV. Fluorescents (standard tube OR compact type) - emit tons of UV but then the coating converts it to visible. Areas where the coating have worn out will emit some UV but tend to be small areas. The coating itself will not tend to emit UV. “black light” and “tanning bed” bulbs however have little or no coating and emit almost ALL UV. They won’t emit much infrared, and what they emit is due to their temperature. LED bulbs generally emit ZERO UV at all, but they will have some infrared radiation from their base area where the power conversion electronics are at but none from the LED itself (LEDs themselves).
